In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle ACB = 50^\circ$ and $\angle CBA = 70^\circ$. Thus, $\angle CAB = 180^\circ - 50^\circ - 70^\circ = 60^\circ$.
Since $AD \perp BC$, $\angle ADC = 90^\circ$. In $\triangle ADC$, $\angle DAC = 180^\circ - 90^\circ - 50^\circ = 40^\circ$.
Since $AE$ is a diameter, $\angle ABE = 90^\circ$ (angle inscribed in a semicircle).
$\angle AEB = 90^\circ$.
In $\triangle ABE$, $\angle EAB = 180^\circ - 90^\circ - \angle EBA = 90^\circ - \angle EBA$.
Since $O$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle ABC$, $AO = BO = CO$.
$\angle AOB = 2\angle ACB = 2 \times 50^\circ = 100^\circ$.
$\angle ACB = 50^\circ$.
$AE$ is the diameter. $\angle ABE = 90^\circ$.
$AE$ is a diameter, $\angle ACE = 90^\circ$ (angle inscribed in a semicircle).
$AE$ is a diameter, so $A$, $E$, $O$ are collinear.
Since $\angle AEB = 90^\circ$, $\angle EAB + \angle EBA = 90^\circ$.
$\angle DAE = \angle CAE - \angle CAD$.
$AD \perp BC$. $\angle ADC = 90^\circ$. $\angle CAD = 180^\circ - 90^\circ - \angle ACD = 180^\circ - 90^\circ - 50^\circ = 40^\circ$.
$\angle CAE = \angle CBE = 70^\circ$.
$AE$ is a diameter. $\angle ACE = 90^\circ$.
In cyclic quadrilateral $ABCE$, $\angle BAC + \angle BEC = 180^\circ$. $\angle BEC = 180^\circ - 60^\circ = 120^\circ$.
$\angle ACB = 50^\circ$.
In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle BAC = 60^\circ$. $\angle DAB = 60^\circ - 40^\circ = 20^\circ$.
Consider $\angle CAE$. In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle BAC = 60^\circ$.
$\angle CAE$ is an inscribed angle.
$\angle CAE = \angle CBE = 70^\circ$ (angle on the same arc).
In quadrilateral $ABCE$, $\angle CAB + \angle CEB = 180^\circ$.
$\angle CBE = 70^\circ$. $\angle CAB = 60^\circ$.
$\angle DAB = 40^\circ$, $\angle CAE = 60^\circ$. $\angle DAE = 20^\circ$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{20}$
